October 12, 1980: Fiction
FIRESTARTER, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Eight year old Charlie can look
at anything and turn it into flames.
THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in
Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942.
THE FIFTH HORSEMAN, by Larry Collins and Dominique Lapierre. (Simon &
Schuster, $13.95.) Libyan terrorists have planted a thermonuclear device in New
York and there are only 24 hours to find it.
RAGE OF ANGELS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $12.95.) An idealistic young
woman lawyer triumphs over two vengeful men.
FANNY, by Erica Jong. (New American Library, $12.95.) The adventures of a lusty
18th-century Englishwoman.
THE ORIGIN, by Irving Stone. (Doubleday, $14.95.) Biographical novel of Charles
Darwin.
LOON LAKE, by E.L. Doctorow. (Random House, $11.95.) The strange, lyrical
adventures of a young man during the Depression.
THE TENTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A
junior lawyer sets out to unravel the strange conduct of some of his firm's
important clients.
THE SPIKE, by Arnaud de Borchgrave and Robert Moss. (Crown, $12.95.)
Newsman on the trail of a Soviet conspiracy.
RANDOM WINDS, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $11.95.) Three generations of
doctors and their families.
THE CLAN OF THE CAVE BEAR, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $12.95.) A saga of
Cro-Magnon and Neanderthal men, who inhabited Europe 35,000 years ago.
KANE & ABEL, by Jeffrey Archer. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Battles in a
corporation boardroom between new money and old.
SINS OF THE FATHERS, by Susan Howatch. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.)
Rivalries and intrigue in the family of a ruthless tycoon.
THE BOURNE IDENTITY, by Robert Ludlum. (Richard Marek, $12.95.) The
melodramatic adventures of an amnesiac trying to find out who he really is.
THE SECOND COMING, by Walker Percy. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) A
retired lawyer finds a new life through an attractive young neighbor.
October 12, 1980
Non-Fiction
CRISIS INVESTING, by Douglas R. Casey. (Stratford Press/Harper, $12.50.)
''Opportunities for investing in the coming Great Depression.''
SHELLEY: ALSO KNOWN AS SHIRLEY, by Shelley Winters. (Morrow, $14.95.) A
Brooklyn ghetto girl's progress to three homes, two Oscars, six mink coats and
ninety-nine films.
MUSIC FOR CHAMELEONS, by Truman Capote. (Random House, $10.95.)
Reminiscences, vignettes and a long fact-crime piece.
FREE TO CHOOSE, by Milton & Rose Friedman. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$9.95.) The Nobel laureate economist and his wife discuss the relationship of
government and the economy: tie-in to the PBS television series.
CRAIG CLAIBORNE'S GOURMET DIET, by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey.
(Times Books, $10.95.) Recipes for eating well, losing weight and maintaining
good health.
THE SKY'S THE LIMIT, by Wayne Dyer. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) How to
achieve perfection of body and mind.
NOTHING DOWN, by Robert G. Allen. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) How to buy
real estate with little or no cash.
INGRID BERGMAN: MY STORY, by Ingrid Bergman and Alan Burgess.
(Delacorte, $14.95.) The actress's personal life as well as her career.
GOODBYE, DARKNESS: A Memoir of the Pacific War, by William Manchester.
(Little, Brown, $14.95.) Action as a Marine.
LYNDON, by Merle Miller. (Putnam's, $17.95.) Firsthand memories of Johnson
from hundreds of interviews.
THE THIRD WAVE, by Alvin Toffler. (Morrow, $14.95.) The changes our society is
about to undergo: a pop prognosticator's analysis.
ANATOMY OF AN ILLNESS, by Norman Cousins. (Norton, $9.95.) A patient's
account of his successful fight against a serious disease.
LITTLE GLORIA ... HAPPY AT LAST, by Barbara Goldsmith. (Knopf, $15.95.) The
family struggle to gain possession of young Gloria Vanderbilt and her fortune.
NUMBER 1, by Billy Martin and Peter Golenbock. (Delacorte, $9.95.) The feisty
baseball manager's troubles and triumphs.
HOW YOU CAN BECOME FINANCIALLY INDEPENDENT BY INVESTING IN
REAL ESTATE, by Albert J. Lowry. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) How-to.
